For the given options: (1) Sell 1 $27 put for $0.3, (2) Buy 1 $25 put for $0.12, (3) Sell 1 $33 call for $0.21, and (4) Buy 1 $34 call for $0.12. The breakeven stock price(s) are $25.00 and $33.20.

The breakeven stock price for option (1) is $25.00. This is because when the stock price is below $25.00 at expiration, the put will be exercised and the option seller will be assigned 100 shares at $27, resulting in a loss of $2.00 per share ($27.00 - $25.00). This loss is offset by the $0.30 premium received from selling the put, resulting in a net loss of $1.70 per share ($2.00 - $0.30).

The breakeven stock price for option (2) is also $25.00. This is because when the stock price is below $25.00 at expiration, the put will be exercised and the option buyer will be assigned 100 shares at $25.00, resulting in a profit of $0.12 per share ($25.00 - $24.88). This profit is offset by the $0.12 premium paid for the put, resulting in a net profit of $0.00 per share ($0.12 - $0.12).

1. Let's start with the put options:
`Sell (1)$27 strike price put at $0.3`
`Buy (1)$25 strike price put at $0.12`

If the stock price drops below $25, the sold put will be in-the-money, resulting in a loss of $2 ($27 strike price - $25 stock price - $0.3 premium).
However, the owned put will also be in-the-money, resulting in a gain of $2 ($27 strike price - $25 stock price + $0.12 premium).
So the net loss is $0 ($2 - $2).

On the other hand, if the stock price rises above $27, the sold put will be out-of-the-money, resulting in no loss or gain. The owned put will also be out-of-the-money, resulting in a loss of $0.12 (premium).
So the net loss is $0.12.

The maximum loss for the put options is $0.12.

2. Now let's look at the call options:
`Sell (1)$33 strike price call at $0.21`
`Buy (1)$34 strike price call at $0.12`

If the stock price rises above $34, the sold call will be in-the-money, resulting in a loss of $1 ($34 stock price - $33 strike price - $0.21 premium).
The owned call will be out-of-the-money, resulting in no loss or gain.
So the net loss is $1.
